comments.commentBody: Usually a new administration picks the leaders from an older administration to fill key positions. Trump is picking from a list of former administration castoffs, people deemed ill suited, unfit or unqualified.  You thought the Cheney, Rumsfeld, Wolfowitz show was bad? Doesn't anyone have a memory?

I never thought I'd see anything like this after Richard Nixon was run out of office. I am desperately looking for the next Barbara Jordan in Congress to remind us of what is right and what is just plain wrong.

Somebody please step forward.

The paragraph in this op-ed piece that talks about the immigration system and the views of Senator Sessions was the most disheartening to me, although the entire piece makes me feel despondent.  I can't image a 30 percent increase in the federal prison population and the lives this would ruin, in addition to the incredibly negative impact to our society.  I just can't believe that weeks ago we were talking about the possibility of prison and immigration reforms and now that seems like such an impossible long shot.  This appointment for Attorney General of someone with such enmity towards the progress of black Americans and immigrants is just heartbreaking.

I don't want Sessions as AG for obvious reasons. But, as a career prosecutor I believe this editorial badly misses the mark. There are voter id laws in more than half the states, many of which have Democrat attorneys general. If they care to, these State AG's can bring more lawsuits against voter id laws than the Justice Department, and they probably will. If Sessions wants to focus on non-existent voter fraud, that seems like a good idea to me. He'll get nowhere fast. As for criminal justice reform, that is the work of Congress, not the AG. Too many nonviolent drug cases are a ridiculous policy, but such cases almost all are tried in local courts, before and after Holder's reform. Finally, immigration cases --other than illegal re-entry -- are overseen by Homeland Security, not the Department of Justice. So Sessions has a very limited role.

The greatest harm that Sessions can cause is by not approving cases which should be brought and cannot be brought by the states. And, secondly, by bringing cases that are losers for political reasons. If he does this, he will demoralize many career Justice employees, who may well leave in large numbers.

I have said this a million times. The Editorial Board needs a lawyer. Worrying about immigration cases that Sessions won't touch is embarrassing for a high school newspaper.

I've hired hundreds of people in my career.  I've noticed that A players want A players around them.  They try to hire better than themselves, and to complement their strengths.  Arrogant, C players on the other hand, look for fealty first, then capability, and then only acquire other C players. Add in the narcissistic factor of Dear Leader, how can the best people even be considered in such an environment?  Every appointment, except by accident, will individually and collectively further erode trust in our government.

Sessions, Flynn, Bannon--why is anyone surprised by this? Did Trump at any point indicate he would do anything differently? The people who voted for him (or stayed home), and will be negatively affected by all this, deserve exactly what they get.

People who get roughed up illegally by police or self-appointed vigilantes, people who lose out on health care or government services (who voted for Trump thinking he cared about them), people who will be poisoned by companies who feel, correctly, that the new government has no interest whatsoever in protecting them---ANY of them who voted for Trump deserve exactly what they get.

As for the rest of the country--and a majority of American voters--we'd like a rematch, please, this time with verifiable paper ballots only, preferably counted by election observers from the EU.

Imposing longer sentences on those charged and found guilty of minor, non-violent drug crimes and also refusing to parole those already imprisoned under long term mandatory sentences will only result in a greater burden to the states and taxpayers. Not too forget the burden that comes to families when both young and old are taken from their families, loved ones and out of the community.  Mr. Sessions and Mr. Trump need to be called out on this travesty and Democrats need to organize to keep Mr. Sessions from the position of attorney general. Mr. Sessions has not change over the years. He is a racist, bigoted angry man who lost a judgeship and now he is seeking revenge.  He'll exact that revenge from every minority and minor user of drugs that is caught in the web of justice. Prisons will overflow. The courts will be overburdened and our communities and citizens will suffer long and unjust incarceration. We must oppose this nomination with great intensity.  It is time for Democrats to mobilize.

I worked for Senator Sessions as an intern, and he is a man of integrity and character. Condemning someone over one or two statements that they may or may not have made in their youth is not fair, given his outstanding record and dedication to law and order.  I saw nothing that remotely resembled racism throughout my interaction with him. He would be an outstanding attorney general.
Michael Flynn and Jeff Sessions?  Really?  On inauguration day, don't forget to set your watches back 67 years.

Donald Trump asked Black Americans to vote for him, asking: "What do you have to lose?"  A big part of the answer to his question, as far as Black. Americans are concerned, is found in Trump's naming of Sessions as Attorney General.

All of Trump's picks are just great. He was elected to shake up the elites, and has done so by picking stringent ideologues for key positions.
Mission accomplished!

No! to Jeff Sessions! He is a racist through and through. I grew up in the Deep South. He is the epitome of the entitled white (and male) racist Southerner. 

Growing up in the South as a white girl, I have heard "jokes" like his all my life. These jokes are code, signals to other white Southerners that say, "Don't worry, I hate them, too. You're safe with me."

Just a quick analysis of Sessions' Klan joke reveals that it cannot be funny to anyone who doesn't hold a racist belief: "pot smoking is much worse than injustice against blacks, even injustice in the form of physical harm." Ha ha. Get it?

His excuse in his confirmation to be named a judge was that he was joking. But it's not funny, and only a racist could laugh at it or tell it.

This man must NOT become the top justice official in our nation.

Sessions grew up in segregated Alabama.  It doesn't surprise me that he made racist statements 30 years ago.  Now he's an ultraconservative Senator, supported by the Tea Party. I don't care much what he said 30 yeas ago.  I think he's wrong for the job because he's a Tea Party-supported kook.

What's with the anti-marijuana stance of anybody President-Elect Trump is appointing?

Isn't the whole conservative movement about less federal intrusion into states' rights?

If the new government considers abortion a completely states' rights issue, then shouldn't the whole drug use fall under states' rights now?

Isn't the goal of these appointee choices to roll back the clock to when America was Great? That means the 1950s, before the whole silly civil rights movement and women began hoping for equal pay for equal work time.

America is getting just what we elected the man to do. He told us exactly what he would do and he is doing it.

I have tried to keep an open mind with respect to Mr. Trump and the future of our country, but it is increasingly difficult when assessing the policy positions of these early administrative appointments.  What I find even more distressing is how quickly the Never-Trumpers have coalesced around this temperamentally unfit president elect.  As if talk of Muslim registries, and mass deportations is not frightening enough, we will soon have a white supremacist attorney general and a Jacksonian NSA chief.  Will someone please awaken me from this nightmare?

"Good people don't smoke marijuana."  Good people don't embrace the KKK.  Good people, and the U.S. Constitution don't discriminate on the basis of race, gender, age or religion.  THe south lost the war, and we ain't going back.  As an old, southern white guy, count me 1 No TRump.  Sessions shouldn't be confirmed as dog catcher.
Bring it on.  We get the leaders we deserve.  Any free country that elects a Donald Trump surely deserves a Jeff Sessions.
